messageBody:
"Heath, Joseph" wrote:

> You have to make a distinction between public and private level methods..
> Personally I javadoc my public methods as these will be visible outside the
> class (maybe without hte source being visible).

I find myself using 'private' methods less these days. For 'public' and 'protected' methods, I'll attempt first to make the method cohesive and give it a signature that's as expressive as possible . If the signature still isn't completely obvious as to the intent of the method, or there's something particularly interesting about the method behavior, then I'll add JavaDoc.

>
> I sort of agree with the idea that that tests can be used to document
> methods but have these problems with that:
> 1. Tests do not explain the methods, merely give examples of use.

Examples constitute explanation to some degree, IMO. In cases where the method does something particularly interesting, as mentioned above, I'll try to add a test to explain the behavior in addition to adding JavaDoc.


>
> 2. Tests do show intention of the method, just the implementation (we're
> back to the "the implementation is not the design argument").
>

Rather, they show the intention, and _not_ the implementation.

Is that what you meant to say?

Mike
